message: Hi, Steve, care to explain why you deleted the info about Lunt? He is not a random independent researcher who came up with a theory. He is the first and most ardent promoter of Macedonian linguistics & historiography in the West, the first westerner to write a Macedonian grammar (with Yugoslav funding) AND a most ardent supporter of Samuel's "Macedonian empire". How impartial would he be to an artifact challenging all that? And are we under a duty to tell readers the backstory? From 1 to 10?
/* Phonology */ I hope that is clear
/* Consonant classification based on place and manner of articulation */ cyrillic template introduction here as well
/* Palatalization of *tj/*gt/*kt and *dj in Bulgarian */ No other choice than to romanise them, I guess
/* Consonants */ angular brackets not needed here I think

Reverted to last version by Vederlo. I don't see how most of the changes are an improvement of any sort. The page needs to have the Cyrillic names formatted with Cyrillic font, not lang|bg and IPAslink > IPA

I have added language templ for all Greek-language words. As the current Cyrillic font is execrable (and there is no Bulgarian Cyrillic to my knowledge), I'll leave the bg inscriptions as is until I find an acceptable solution.
adding languages in accordance with the cleanup request at the top
fixing a number of issues, further sourcing and some expansion

/* Serbo-Croatian */ Well, it is still a nationalistic (I would say chauvinistic) map. And if there is place here for Belic's views, then there should be one for those of Matasic
Quandary about the mix-up of ѣ and ꙗ solved, with additional info and sources
/* The "Macedonian Slavs" in cartography */ This is what caused the change - as claimed by Wilkinson himself.
/* Macedonian separatism */ More on Misirkov's motivation with quotes and links to the text
/* Macedonian separatism */ Again inexact reference, corrected with a direct quote and link to the source text.

/* Alternative dating */ If anything, the current text was worse. I'm in favour of keeping fringe views—as long as they do not take over the entire section and appear to be the mainstream view. So in accordance with this I have expanded the initial paragraph, adding Ugrinova's own opinion, and have trimmed the other paragraphs. It is inexplicable why the fallacious source about Kostic/Velenis (the Edessa church) and the reference to the shape of the letters (ref. to Edessa) was still left
/* Dating */ This entire paragraph seems to be falsified. See explanation for this on Talk page where I am putting it provisionally
/* Ethnic groups */ Adding totals and fixing some errors
/* Subsequent migrations */ Doubled image caption removed from text
/* Ethnic groups */ Revision of the section as per Steve's suggestion that the info is out of scope and my counter-suggestions (you haven't gotten back to me about it). New info all right?
Addition of Werner's hypothesis and link to Kuber

/* Possible Slavs */Jingiby - I agree that they are (quite obviously) not a Slavic tribe, but they appear to have had a not insignificant Panonian Slavic component, so I'm restoring them and moving to a Mixed subcategory

/* Macedonian separatism */ cleanup for better readability
/* Bulgaria */ Clarification about the Blagoevgrad Province

/* Macedonian separatism */ Well-referenced addition to Misirkov
/* Macedonian separatism */ incorrect phrasing on my part

/* Macedonian separatism */ Again, a quote directly contradicts the text. Which Wikipedia guideline says that you can cherry-pick sources and present what is convenient for the narrative and leave out everything that is not? This is POV pushing. Present info fairly. New sentence picked out directly from quote.
/* Medieval period */ adding info about Boris I, the Ohrid literary school, Slavonic liturgy, etc. etc. - with multiple sources and quotes.
Spelling out what these "developments in Slavic culture around Thessaloniki" were
proper reference written out + fixing incorrect time period.
/* Late 19th and early 20th century */ adding direct quote
/* Late 19th and early 20th century */ clarification and better phrasing

/* The designation "Macedonian" */ Yet again, the description in the text directly contradicts the quote that is used to support it. Shapkarev says neither that "Macedonians" is an ethnonym, nor that it has replaced the designation "Bulgarians". He says, very clearly, that the Slavs in Macedonia call themselves Bulgarians in opposition to the other Bulgarians who are referred to as "Shopi". Changes as per source. Please do not manipulate sources.
/* Christianization and adoption of Cyrillic alphabet */ typo, missing s
/* Revisionist assessments */ minor cleanup, all blockquotes reformated
/* Witness reports */ cleanup + shortening for better readability
/* The church */ shortening and cleanup for better readability
/* Massacre */ shortening and cleanup for better readability
/* Uprising in Batak */ cleanup for better readability.
New intro as per sources for better readability
/* Late 19th and early 20th century */ Clarification + separate mention of Anastasovski

/* Late 19th and early 20th century */ I'm bringing some semblance of balance to this section. Antonovski is a graduate student and his views are borderline racist - but fine. However, the statement that "the Slavs in Rumelia were called Bulgarian, which meant nothing more than peasant" is an old racist Serbian trope, which has been refuted time and again by contemporary 19-th century primary sources, who identified Slavs in Kosovo as Serbs and Slavs in Macedonia as Bulgarians
/* History */ Minor cleanup, removing redundant sections, adding info and citations about Rastislav and the development of the alphabet and translation of liturgical texts
Taking this sentence out front. This is an obvious truth to anyone acquainted with the region, but if someone can provide a citation, that will be great.
Final fix + moving the sentence about the separate identification of 142 people in Serbia as Shopi as an ethnos to the appropriate section.
Several new maps added, several quotes added, quotes fixed, links to online sources added, cleanup sign removed as it is clearly not needed any more.
/* Classification */ Adding Cvijic's three maps in a single strip.
/* Languages */ Adding South Slavic dialect continuum map

/* Languages */ Nope. I am removing this map because you have not refuted a single argument of mine. If you want, put [[User:Garygo golob|Garygo golob]]'s map, as you said I put in myself a lot of effort to build a consensus around it, and it is obviously consensual, no one has complained about it, which is a minor miracle for the Balkans. So can we reach an agreement or will we continue to haggle?
Perhaps a better place for it
/* History */ So let's see who will moan about this map:))))

/* Languages */Not sure if the sentence about Macedonian being transitional between Serbian and Bulgarian should exist at all - this is completely untrue. What I have written now at least is, but i don't see much point in it - there is an entire continuum of dialects, we don't need to say it about everything. And about Shopian having "Serbian feature"? Well, doesn't Resava have Bulgarian features? Analytism, only 4 cases, a schwa sound? Sounds pretty Bulgarian to me😉

I am reverting vandalism by User:Vipz, who - as self-proclaimed advocate of the restoration of Serbo-Croatian - does not want to see Bosnian, Croatian and Montenegrin as separate languages on a map. Or are there any other sensible arguments? All three languages are a FACT, and nobody's personal feelings should trump objective truth in Wikipedia.

Uhm... No, Pirin Macedonia is not a thing. But you saying that makes me wonder what your motives are. How about we making the Torlak region "a thing" and post a map that describes it as Bulgarian? If you are principled, you should be really happy with it.  Your argument about the "super simple, country-level map" does not hold. The maps of East and West Slavs are country-level maps and have no dialectal distinction. Maybe oppose them first before reverting. I'm simply levelling the playing field

/* Languages */ I have removed this map because it pushes blatant Macedonian POV, claiming 10% of Bulgarian territory as "Macedonian-speaking". Census results are very clear - this is not true. Yes, the dialect straddling the border is practically the same and is indeed transnational. However, it is NOT okay to claim it for yourself ONLY. Moreover, its size is three times the actual one. NOT okay. I have replaced it with another map, which is uncontroversial as it is entirely census-based.

Map of South Slavic languages added based on existing [[File:Slavic languages map en.svg]] after being truncated and with minor updated, e.g. by adding Montenegrine, enlarging non-Slavic speaking areas in Bulgaria (Turks) and Serbia (Hungarians), adding a small Serbian island in N.Macedonia, etc.

/* South Slavs */ What is the justification for classifying Strymonites and Smolyani as "Sklavenoi"? They were annexed by the First Bulgarian Empire in the 830s, most of them lived in territories that are currently part of Bulgaria (yes, a minority probably did in adjoining Greek territories, but most Slavic speakers there left for Bulgaria in 1913-1926. There can be no comparison here with Ezerites, Melingoi, Rynchines, etc etc. who were eventually hellenized

Moving Smolyani and Strymonites to Bulgarian tribes as they have mostly (if not entirely) inhabited Bulgarian territory. If someone has a sound reason why this should not happen, please state it. There is also a problem with the classification of Baiounitai, as they eventually moved to southern Albania

message: Again deleting this: 1) This is an article I have written myself; 2) It is fully integrated into the main article (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Bulgaria#Historical_birth_and_fertility_rates); 3) I do not intend to write about the topic any more; 4) The article remains as an orphan and a stub and makes no sense to be standalone - so please do not revert it again
There is an article leading to it, Bulgarian Phonology
/* Your submission at Articles for creation: Dimitrina Ignatova-Tzoneva (October 10) */
/* Ohrid recension */ Adding a source for this, I will try to add a bit more info later

/* Ohrid recension */ I just checked the source for Friedman - even though he is a well-known Macedonist supporter, he says nothing of the sort. The request for precise citation has been here for months if not years. Removal of unsourced claims

/* Ohrid recension */ Removal of anachronistic claims about phenomena that took place in later periods. I left more than a week for proper citations to be left, such were not provided. Addition of tj dj developments with proper time period
/* Palatalization of *tj/*gt/*kt and *dj in Bulgarian */ p. 155, not 1955, typo
/* Palatalization of *tj/*gt/*kt and *dj in Bulgarian */ it is Russian here though :)
/* Bulgarian consonantism according to IPA (22-consonant model) */ Correction of table (palatal consonant in other Slavic languages) based on Routledge
why post a ref without explaining or quoting it? Quote added

/* Ohrid recension */ For this too actually. I cannot find this to be a mass phenomenon before the mid 1200s, which - again - is one and a half centuries after OCS. I will be happy to see a source that proves otherwise
/* Palatalisation of *tj/*gt/*kt and *dj in Bulgarian */ 1 w
/* Bulgarian consonantism according to Trubetzkoy (39-consonant model) */ another mistake

/* Ohrid recension */ Same thing: when does this happen (later is not enough) and who says so? This is a common feature of the Middle Bulgarian period, NOT OCS. All these claims make it sound as if something different was happening in the West, which is not the case. What is certain is 1) different development of yers because of stress, 2) early loss of yat, 3) Glagolitics and 4) dz. The rest refers to a much later period and should not be here.

/* Ohrid recension */ Again, in which latter stages? Denasalisation and nasal vowel mixing is assumed to start as early as the 1100 in both East and West. This is not OCS, nor is it a specific "Macedonian" feature

/* Ohrid recension */ In which later stages? The decomposition of sht/zhd into k'/g' in the northernmost parts of Macedonia (under Serbian influence) is usually dated to the Late Middle Ages (1300s-1400s) and even later further south. Can we talk about OCS in 1300-1600?

Sorry, I don't know where this citation has gone:(. I fished it out now. It is Huntley, a Slavonic Languages collection from 1993. There are probably some other missing citations, I lost part of my work at some point

/* First Bulgarian Empire */ Who are the researches other than Horace Lunt? At least anyone else? Also, in the last decades, it has become widely known that he was financed by grants from the Yugloslavian Ministry of Culture, which does not make him particularly trustworthy.
/* Consonants */ This statement is completely incorrect and was not sourced. I have provided a very lengthy quote instead proving the opposite
/* Basis and local influences */ Correcting the IPA symbols for Russian, I had made a mistake before.
/* Palatalisation of *tj/*gt/*kt and *dj in Bulgarian */ Fixing the correct symbols as per IPA
/* Bulgarian consonantism according to IPA (22-consonant model) */ Fixing palatalisation signs to make them more readable.
/* Character of borrowing */ Very unlikely, doubtful and no citation
/* Significant verbs */ translation of headings left in bg
Syntax, Vocabulary, etc. should be separate main headings rather than subheadings underneath phonology

The Bulgarians' opinion about the Shopi, cited by Prof. Carlile Aylmer Macartney has been repetedely deleted by you. This book is a secondary source published several times, incuding by Academic publishing houses as Westview Press. Lang was a Professor at the University of London, specialized in Bulgarian history. Rusyn language is defined by the majority of the scientific community as a regional variety of Ukrainian.  Therefore, it is logical that the Rusyn should be written next to Ukrainian as well as the Silesian language next to Polish.
